info.title: Configuring DHCP server using ISC DHCP

abstract.para: This section explains how to configure ISC DHCP server to provide network configuration and PXE boot information for &productname; 15 installations. The ISC dhcp-server package is not available on &productname; &productnumber; any more. ISC DHCP uses class and subclass matching to support PXE and HTTP boot scenarios across different client architectures.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: ISC DHCP is the traditional DHCP server that provides network configuration and boot file information to PXE clients using a class and subclass system. While ISC has declared this server end-of-life as of 2022, it remains widely used in existing deployments and provides robust support for PXE and HTTP boot scenarios with vendor class identification.

important.title: ISC DHCP end-of-life status
important.para: ISC DHCP has been declared end-of-life by ISC in 2022. For new deployments, consider using Kea or dnsmasq instead. This configuration is provided for compatibility with existing ISC DHCP installations.

section.title: Troubleshooting ISC DHCP configuration
section.para: Common issues when configuring ISC DHCP servers for PXE boot environments.

section.title: Configuration and service issues
section.para: ISC DHCP services may fail to start due to configuration syntax errors or interface binding problems.

section.title: DHCP lease assignment problems
section.para: Clients may fail to receive IP addresses due to subnet configuration or authorization issues.

section.title: Class and subclass matching issues
section.para: PXE clients may receive IP addresses but fail to get correct boot files due to class matching configuration problems.

section.title: DHCPv6 vendor class option issues
section.para: IPv6 DHCP clients have complex vendor class option handling that may require specific configuration for proper PXE boot support.
